docs.title: System Design Journey
docs.text: Welcome to my system design learning journey! This site documents my daily exploration of FAANG-level system design concepts and patterns.

docs.title: About This Journey
docs.text:
I'm following a structured system design plan to build expertise in designing scalable, distributed systems. This site serves as:

  • Daily Learning Log: Track progress and insights from each study session
  • Knowledge Repository: Organize system design concepts and patterns
  • Reference Guide: Quick access to important topics and resources

docs.title: Quick Links
docs.text:
• Daily Logs - Day-by-day learning entries
  • Topics - System design concepts organized by theme
  • Resources - Useful links and references

docs.title: Current Focus
docs.text: Check out the Daily Logs section to see what I'm currently learning.

docs.title: Progress Tracking
docs.text:
This journey is structured to cover:

  • Fundamental system design concepts
  • Scalability and performance optimization
  • Database design and data modeling
  • Distributed systems patterns
  • Real-world system design case studies
  • FAANG-style interview preparation

Last updated: {{ git_revision_date }}

docs.title: About This Project
docs.text: This site documents my journey learning system design concepts, with a focus on preparing for FAANG-level technical interviews and building production-ready systems.

docs.title: Learning Approach
docs.text:
I'm following a structured daily plan that covers:

  1. Fundamental Concepts: Building a solid foundation in distributed systems
  2. Practical Application: Applying concepts to real-world scenarios
  3. Case Studies: Analyzing existing large-scale systems
  4. Practice: Regular design exercises and mock interviews

docs.title: Goals
docs.text:
• Master core system design principles
  • Understand trade-offs in architectural decisions
  • Build confidence in FAANG-level system design interviews
  • Create a comprehensive reference guide for future use

docs.title: Site Structure
docs.text:
This site is built using:

  • MkDocs with Material theme
  • GitHub Pages for hosting
  • Markdown for content
  • Mermaid for diagrams

docs.title: Contact
docs.text:
Feel free to reach out or follow my journey:

  • GitHub: @yourusername

← Back to Home

docs.title: Resources
docs.text: A curated collection of resources for system design learning.

docs.title: Books
docs.text:
• Designing Data-Intensive Applications by Martin Kleppmann
  • System Design Interview by Alex Xu (Volumes 1 & 2)
  • Building Microservices by Sam Newman
  • The Art of Scalability by Martin L. Abbott & Michael T. Fisher

docs.title: Online Courses
docs.text:
• Grokking the System Design Interview
  • System Design Primer (GitHub)
  • ByteByteGo

docs.title: Daily Learning Logs
docs.text: This section contains my day-to-day learning entries, documenting progress, insights, and key takeaways.

docs.title: How to Use This Section
docs.text:
Each daily log entry follows a consistent format:

  • Date: When the learning session occurred
  • Topics Covered: Main concepts explored
  • Key Learnings: Important insights and takeaways
  • Questions: Areas needing further exploration
  • Resources: Links and references used
  • Practice: Design problems or exercises completed

docs.title: Recent Entries
docs.text: Daily logs will appear here as you add them

docs.title: Template for Daily Entries
docs.text:
# Day X - [Date]

## Topics Covered
- Topic 1
- Topic 2

## Key Learnings
- Key insight 1
- Key insight 2

## System Design Concepts
### Concept Name
Description and notes

## Questions to Explore
- [ ] Question 1
- [ ] Question 2

## Resources
- [Link 1](url)
- [Link 2](url)

## Practice Problems
- Problem description and solution approach

## Reflections
What went well, what to improve

docs.title: Archive by Month
docs.text:
Organize your logs by month as they grow

← Back to Home

docs.title: Topics Covered
docs.text:
• Setting up learning environment
  • GitHub Pages and MkDocs setup
  • System design learning plan overview

docs.title: Key Learnings
docs.text:
• Organized approach to system design learning is crucial
  • Documentation helps solidify understanding
  • Daily logging creates accountability and tracks progress

docs.title: Documentation as Learning Tool
docs.text: Creating a public learning journal serves multiple purposes: - Forces clear articulation of concepts - Creates a personal reference guide - Demonstrates learning progression to potential employers

docs.title: Questions to Explore
docs.text:
• [ ] What are the fundamental building blocks of distributed systems?
  • [ ] How do tech companies approach system design interviews?
  • [ ] What are the most common scalability patterns?

docs.title: Resources
docs.text:
• MkDocs Material Theme Documentation
  • System Design Primer

docs.title: Practice Problems
docs.text: To be added as I progress through the curriculum

docs.title: Reflections
docs.text: Today was about setting up the foundation for my learning journey. The site structure is ready, and I'm excited to start filling it with knowledge. The key is consistency - committing to daily learning and documentation.

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
• [ ] Start with fundamental system design concepts
  • [ ] Review the FAANG system design plan in detail
  • [ ] Complete first system design case study

← Back to Daily Logs | Home

docs.title: System Design Topics
docs.text: This section organizes system design concepts by theme for easy reference and review.

docs.title: Scalability
docs.text:
• Horizontal vs Vertical Scaling
  • Load Balancing
  • Caching Strategies
  • Content Delivery Networks (CDN)

docs.title: Data Storage
docs.text:
• SQL vs NoSQL
  • Database Sharding
  • Replication and Partitioning
  • Data Consistency Models

docs.title: System Architecture
docs.text:
• Microservices vs Monolithic
  • Event-Driven Architecture
  • Message Queues
  • API Design (REST, GraphQL, gRPC)

docs.title: Performance
docs.text:
• Latency vs Throughput
  • Caching Layers
  • Indexing Strategies
  • Database Optimization

docs.title: Reliability
docs.text:
• High Availability
  • Fault Tolerance
  • Disaster Recovery
  • Monitoring and Observability

docs.title: Security
docs.text:
• Authentication and Authorization
  • Rate Limiting
  • Data Encryption
  • DDoS Protection

docs.title: Common System Design Patterns
docs.text:
• Load Balancer Pattern
  • Cache-Aside Pattern
  • CQRS (Command Query Responsibility Segregation)
  • Event Sourcing
  • Circuit Breaker
  • Saga Pattern
  • Database Per Service

docs.title: Real-World System Designs
docs.text:
This section will grow with case studies of popular systems

  • URL Shortener (like bit.ly)
  • Social Media Feed (like Twitter/X)
  • Video Streaming Platform (like YouTube)
  • E-commerce Platform (like Amazon)
  • Ride-Sharing Service (like Uber)
  • Chat Application (like WhatsApp)
  • File Storage System (like Dropbox)
